name: Aad Fort
key_events: Minor watchtower fort
notes: A small  lesser-known fort covered in dense vegetation.

name: Achala Fort
key_events: Part of Satmala hill range forts; Captured by British in 1818
notes: Twin fort to Ahivantgad, offers great views of the region.

name: Achalpur Fort
key_events: Capital of Berar Sultanate
notes: Located inside the city, known for its massive gates and walls.

name: Adas Fort
key_events: Minor watchtower fort
notes: A small fort primarily used as a watch post.

name: Ahiwantgad
key_events: Treaty of Purandar; Captured by British
notes: Twin fort to Achala fort, features large caves and water cisterns.

name: Ahmednagar Fort
key_events: Imprisonment of Jawaharlal Nehru and other freedom fighters during Quit India Movement, 1942
notes: One of the best-designed land forts in India; currently under Indian military control.

name: Ajinkyatara
key_events: Capital of the Satara state; Captured by British in 1818
notes: Overlooks Satara city; accessible by road; popular for morning walks.

name: Ajmera
key_events: Small watchtower fort
notes: A lesser-known fort, offers good views of the surrounding region.

name: Ajoba
key_events: Pilgrimage site for Valmiki Rishi; has a "cradle of Sita" pinnacle
notes: Primarily a pilgrimage trek with some fortifications near the top.

name: Akluj Fort
key_events: Seat of the Mohite-Patil family
notes: A residential fort (gadi) still partly occupied by descendants.

name: Akola Fort
key_events: Important stronghold in Berar region
notes: Located in the old city area of Akola; features multiple gates.

name: Alang Fort
key_events: Part of the intense Alang-Madan-Kulang trek
notes: Part of the toughest trek in the Sahyadris; requires technical climbing gear.

name: Amalner
key_events: Local administrative fort (gadi)
notes: A land fort in Amalner town  now heavily encroached.

name: Ambagad
key_events: Controlled by Gonds; later by Bhonsles of Nagpur
notes: A small fort with scenic views of the surrounding region.

name: Ambolgad
key_events: Coastal watch post
notes: A small coastal fort offering splendid views of the Arabian Sea.

name: Anghai
key_events: Controlled trade routes; has Jain and Hindu caves
notes: Note: This is an alternate name for Ankai Fort (ID 014).

name: Anjaneri Fort
key_events: Believed to be the birthplace of Lord Hanuman
notes: Features a temple for Anjani Mata; popular pilgrimage and trek spot.

name: Ankai Fort
key_events: Controlled trade routes; has Jain and Hindu caves
notes: Twin fort to Tankai; known for its extensive cave complexes and fortifications.

name: Antur Fort
key_events: Protected the Gautala Wildlife Sanctuary region
notes: Known for its scenic location and robust construction.

name: Arjungad
key_events: Guarded the route to Rajapur port
notes: A small fort with minimal structures remaining.

name: Arnala Fort
era: Sultanate of Gujarat; Portuguese; Maratha Empire
key_events: Captured from the Portuguese by Chimaji Appa
notes: Island fort accessible by ferry from Arnala village.

name: Asava
key_events: Guarded the Palghar region
notes: A plateau fort with several water cisterns and remnants of fortifications.

name: Asheri Fort
key_events: Captured from Portuguese by Marathas in 1737
notes: Offers panoramic views of the Palghar region; has a large plateau.

name: Avandha Fort
key_events: Important fort in the Kalsubai range; surrendered to the British
notes: A challenging trek with rewarding views of Patta and Kalsubai.

name: Avchitgad
key_events: Strengthened during Nizamshahi period
notes: Known for its two main gates and bastions still in good condition.

name: Bahadurgad
key_events: Aurangzeb's major Deccan campaign base; renamed Bahadurgad from Pedgaon
notes: Known for its Bhuleshwar temple and historical significance during Mughal-Maratha wars.

name: Bahadurpur
key_events: A land fort guarding the trade routes of Khandesh
notes: Located in Bahadurpur village most of the structure is now gone.

name: Bahadurwadi
key_events: A small land fort or 'gadi'
notes: Very little remains of the original structure.

name: Bahiravgad
key_events: Guarded the Koyna valley; known for its deadly exposure
notes: Extremely difficult and dangerous trek; involves a vertical rock patch.

name: Bahula Fort
key_events: Watchtower fort in the Trimbak range
notes: A lesser-known fort offering solitude and views of Nashik city.

name: Balapur Fort
key_events: Strategically located on the banks of Man river
notes: Features high walls, bastions, and a beautiful chhatri of Mirza Raja Jai Singh.

name: Ballalgad
key_events: Watchtower fort near the coast
notes: A small fort  largely in ruins.

name: Ballalpur Fort
key_events: Capital of the Gond Kingdom before Chandrapur
notes: Located on the east bank of the Wardha River.

name: Balwantgad
key_events: Small fort near Khed
notes: A small fort with very little historical record.

name: Banda Fort
key_events: Guarded the Terekhol creek crossing
notes: A land fort in the town of Banda  with only a few walls remaining.

name: Bandra Fort
key_events: Watchtower at Mahim Bay; captured by Marathas in 1739
notes: Note: This is a duplicate entry for Castella de Aguada (ID 040).

name: Bankot Fort
key_events: First fort captured by Shivaji on the Konkan coast
notes: Offers a panoramic view of the Savitri river meeting the Arabian sea.

name: Barvai
key_events: Watchtower fort near Barvi Dam
notes: The fort overlooks the Barvi dam and is mostly in a state of ruin.

name: Basgad
key_events: Watchtower fort overlooking Harihar and Trimbak range
notes: Known for its unique rock-cut steps and a small temple.

name: Belapur Fort
key_events: Captured by the Portuguese and later by the Marathas under Chimaji Appa
notes: Located near the Panvel creek; now houses government offices.

name: Bhadravati Fort
key_events: Ancient fort also known as Bhandak
notes: Notable for ancient temples and Buddhist caves in the vicinity.

name: Bhagwantgad
key_events: Built to counter the Portuguese at Terekhol
notes: A small coastal fort, mostly in ruins but offers great sea views.

name: Bhairavgad (Kothale)
key_events: Guarded the Koyna valley; known for its deadly exposure
notes: Note: This is the Bhairavgad in the Koyna region, famous for its dangerous climb.

name: Bhairavgad (Moroshi)
key_events: Watchtower fort in Malshej Ghat region
notes: Note: This is the Bhairavgad near Malshej Ghat, known for its unique rock architecture.

name: Bhandardurg
key_events: The 'Jewel' fort; famous for its 'Nedhe' or Needle Hole
notes: Note: This is an alternate name for Ratangad (ID 167).

name: Bhangsimatagad
key_events: A small hill fort for watchtower purposes
notes: A very obscure fort with almost no remains.

name: Bharatgad
key_events: Built to protect the southern borders of the Maratha kingdom
notes: Sister fort to Bhagwantgad.

name: Bhaskargad
key_events: Watchtower fort overlooking Harihar and Trimbak range
notes: Known for its unique rock-cut steps and a small temple.

name: Bhavangad
key_events: Watchtower on the Dahanu-Nashik route
notes: A small and simple fort trek.

name: Bhilai Fort
key_events: Ancient Gond fort
notes: An obscure fort with mostly earthen ramparts remaining.

name: Bhivgad
key_events: Small fort near Karjat
notes: A small and easy trek offering views of Dhak Bahiri and Peb forts.

name: Bhorgad
key_events: Watchtower fort in the Selbari range
notes: A lesser-known fort with excellent views of the surrounding ranges.

name: Bhorgiri
key_events: Known for its caves and proximity to Bhimashankar
notes: More of a pilgrimage site with caves and minor fortifications.

name: Bhudargad
key_events: Important administrative center for the region
notes: A vast fort with several temples and administrative buildings.

name: Bhupalgad
key_events: Destroyed by Sambhaji Maharaj in a campaign against the Mughals
notes: Note: This is a different fort from Bhupatgad (Palghar).

name: Bhupatgad
key_events: Built to watch over the northern Konkan region
notes: Features several water cisterns and remnants of structures.

name: Bhushangad
key_events: A guardian fort for the eastern frontiers of Swarajya
notes: Features a temple of Maruti and a large well.

name: Birwadi Fort
key_events: Watchtower fort near Raigad
notes: A small fort good for beginner trekkers.

name: Bishta
key_events: A small fortified settlement or 'gadi'
notes: Hardly any structure remains today.

name: Bitangad
key_events: Small fort used as a watchtower
notes: Trek is easy and offers views of Kalsubai, Alang, and Madan.

name: Bombay Castle
key_events: Headquarters of the British East India Company in Bombay
notes: Located within the premises of INS Angre, the naval base of the Western Naval Command. Access is restricted.

name: Brahmagiri
key_events: Source of the Godavari River; a major pilgrimage site
notes: More of a pilgrimage site with fortifications; features Ganga-Godavari temple.

name: Castella de Aguada
key_events: Watchtower at Mahim Bay; captured by Marathas in 1739
notes: Popular landmark in Bandra; offers views of the Bandra-Worli Sea Link.

name: Chambhargad
key_events: A small fort known for its rock-cut cave
notes: A lesser-known fort offering views of the Koyna backwaters.

name: Chandan Fort
key_events: Twin fort to Vandan; captured by Shivaji Maharaj
notes: The trek usually covers both Chandan and Vandan forts together.

name: Chanderi
key_events: A watchtower fort between Badlapur and Vangani
notes: A popular trek known for its huge pinnacle and caves.

name: Chandragad
key_events: Overlooks the backwaters of Varasgaon dam
notes: A remote fort with a hidden escape route (chor darwaja).

name: Chandwad Fort
key_events: Known for Rangmahal palace and ancient temples
notes: Fort is located above the town of Chandwad.

name: Chaughan Fort
key_events: Part of the Satmala hill range
notes: A less-frequented fort with remnants of fortifications.

name: Chaulher Fort
key_events: Known for its difficult access and strong fortifications
notes: Features a large plateau and a narrow, rock-cut approach.

name: Chavand Fort
key_events: One of the five forts of Junnar region; has a Saptamatrika plaque
notes: The fort was renamed Prasannagad by Shivaji Maharaj.

name: Danda Fort
key_events: Guarded the Revdanda creek
notes: Note: This likely refers to Korlai Fort (ID 099), located near Danda-Rajpuri creek.

name: Dasgaon Fort
key_events: Guarded the Savitri River creek
notes: Located on a small hillock near the village of Dasgaon.

name: Dategad
key_events: Watchtower fort guarding the Patan-Karad region
notes: A small fort with a temple and a few water cisterns.

name: Dativre Fort
key_events: Guarded the mouth of Dativre creek
notes: Almost completely ruined; located amidst a fishing village.

name: Daulatabad Fort
key_events: Capital shifted from Delhi by Muhammad bin Tughlaq in 1327
notes: Features Chand Minar, intricate defenses, and the Andheri (dark passage).

name: Daulatmangal
key_events: Built to keep a watch on the movement of Marathas
notes: Built on a hill that also hosts the famous Bhuleshwar Temple.

name: Dermal Fort
key_events: Small watchtower fort
notes: Note: This is a duplicate entry for Dermal Fort (ID 050).

name: Devgad Fort
key_events: Protected the Devgad harbour; has a lighthouse
notes: The fort walls enclose the Devgad town and harbour.

name: Dhak Bahiri
key_events: A cave shrine of Lord Bhairavnath, known for extreme trek
notes: Note: This is a duplicate entry for Dhak Bahiri (ID 052).

name: Dharavi Fort
key_events: Built to mark the northern boundary of British-held Bombay
notes: Note: This is a duplicate entry for Riwa Fort (ID 170).

name: Dharmapuri Fort
key_events: Ancient land fort with a temple
notes: The fort is mostly in ruins but the Kedareshwar temple is intact.

name: Dhodap Fort
key_events: Second highest fort in Maharashtra; Treaty of Purandar
notes: Famous for its unique shape, Ikhara cliff, and rock-cut architecture.

name: Dhotri Fort
key_events: A small watchtower fort
notes: Minimal ruins remain.

name: Dronagiri Fort
key_events: Overlooks Karanja and Mumbai harbours
notes: Much of the fort area is now part of a naval base and ONGC plant.

name: Dubergad
key_events: A small hill fort with minimal remains
notes: A lesser-known trek in the Dindori region.

name: Dundha Fort
key_events: Small fort with a few cisterns and minimal fortifications
notes: A simple trek near Nashik.

name: Durg Dhakoba
key_events: Twin peak to Dhakoba, guarded the ancient trade routes
notes: A challenging trek often combined with Dhakoba.

name: Durgadi Fort
key_events: Site of the first Maratha navy dockyard
notes: A small fort on the banks of Ulhas river; has a popular Durga temple.

name: Fattegad
key_events: Small watchtower fort
notes: Lesser known fort  mostly ruins remain.

name: Gagangad
key_events: Famous for the Gagangiri Maharaj Math
notes: Accessible by road; primarily a pilgrimage site now.

name: Galna Fort
key_events: Controlled the Surat-Burhanpur trade route
notes: A historical fort with a mix of Hindu and Islamic architecture.

name: Gambhirgad
key_events: Guarded the northern Konkan region
notes: Known for its dense forest trek and panoramic views.

name: Gandharvagad
key_events: Small fort known for its caves
notes: A remote fort with scenic surroundings.

name: Gawilgad
key_events: Major stronghold in Berar; captured by British under Arthur Wellesley in 1803
notes: Located in Melghat Tiger Reserve; known for its intricate carvings and massive walls.

name: Ghangad
key_events: Watchtower fort near Tamhini Ghat
notes: Recently restored with ladders for the final climb.

name: Gharapuri
key_events: Site of Elephanta Caves; had two cannons on top
notes: The fort structure is minimal  known primarily for the UNESCO World Heritage caves.

name: Ghargad
key_events: A small fort known for its thrilling rock patch
notes: Trek involves a narrow chimney-style rock climb.

name: Ghodbunder Fort
key_events: Controlled trade on Ulhas river; has a church within
notes: The fort is now used for government training purposes.

name: Ghosalgad
key_events: Paired with Talgad to guard the Mandad river creek
notes: Offers great views of the surrounding valleys and forts like Kuda Caves.

name: Ghotavade Fort
key_events: A small hillock fort
notes: Almost no structure remains just a small hill.

name: Goa Fort (Harnai)
key_events: Land-based fort connected to the sea fort Suvarnadurg
notes: Note: This is one of the three land forts protecting Suvarnadurg.

name: Gojagad
key_events: Small watchtower fort
notes: A simple and short trek with ruins of a gateway.

name: Gopalgad
key_events: Guarded the Dabhol creek; renamed Gopalgad by Shivaji Maharaj
notes: Note: This is a duplicate entry for Anjanvel Fort (ID 013).

name: Gorakhgad
key_events: Pilgrimage site with a challenging rock pinnacle
notes: Famous for its rock-cut steps and a large cave that can accommodate many trekkers.

name: Gorakhgad (Manmad)
key_events: A hillock near Ankai-Tankai with some fortifications
notes: Note: This is a smaller fort near Ankai, different from Gorakhgad near Murbad.

name: Gowalkot Fort
key_events: Guarded the Vashishti river and the port of Chiplun
notes: Overlooks the town of Chiplun and the river.

name: Gunvantgad
key_events: Guarded the route to Mahabaleshwar
notes: A straightforward trek with a temple at the top.

name: Hadsar Fort
key_events: Known for its uniquely carved entrance tunnel and rock-cut steps
notes: One of the five forts around Junnar.

name: Hanumantgad
key_events: Small fort in the Bhudargad range
notes: A scenic trek through dense forest.

name: Hanumantgad (Junnar)
key_events: Twin fort to Nimgiri; has several rock-cut cisterns
notes: Note: This is the Hanumantgad that is a twin to Nimgiri Fort.

name: Hanumantgad (Sindhudurg)
key_events: A forest fort on the Goa-Maharashtra border
notes: Note: This is a different fort from the one in Kolhapur district.

name: Hargad
key_events: Part of the Mulher-Mora-Hargad fort trio
notes: A companion fort to Mulher often trekked together.

name: Harihar Fort
key_events: Guarded the Gonda Ghat trade route
notes: Famous for its iconic 80-degree inclined rock-cut steps.

name: Harishchandragad
key_events: Features Konkan Kada; Kedareshwar Cave; Taramati Peak
notes: A vast plateau fort; a paradise for trekkers and nature lovers.

name: Hatgad
key_events: Guarded the route into Gujarat
notes: Located near the Saputara hill station; accessible by well-laid steps.

name: Indragad
key_events: Features a large number of caves
notes: Note: This is an alternate name for Indrai Fort (ID 074).

name: Indrai Fort
key_events: Features a large number of caves
notes: Known for its huge cave complex that can house hundreds of people.

name: Induri Fort
key_events: Built on the banks of the Indrayani river
notes: Known for the samadhi of Sarsenapati Khanderao Dabhade.

name: Irshalgad
key_events: Sister fort to Prabalgad; used as a watchtower
notes: A pinnacle fort with a small area on top; the final climb is tricky.

name: Jaigad Fort
key_events: Guarded the Shastri river creek; has a lighthouse nearby
notes: A large coastal fort offering spectacular views of the sea and creek.

name: Jamgaon Fort
key_events: Known for its beautiful pillared mansion (wada)
notes: The main attraction is the well-preserved wada inside the fort walls.

name: Janjala Fort
key_events: A large hill fort with extensive fortifications
notes: Known for its two levels of fortification and rock-hewn caves.

name: Janjira
key_events: Remained unconquered by Marathas; Portuguese; and British
notes: Note: This is the common name for Murud-Janjira Fort (ID 133).

name: Jawalya
key_events: A small fort in the Satmala hill range
notes: A lesser-known fort offering views of the surrounding range.

name: Jivdhan Fort
key_events: Guarded the Naneghat trade route; features Vanderlingi pinnacle
notes: Part of the 'Famous 5' treks of the Junnar region; involves a rock patch.

name: Jungli Jaigad
key_events: A remote forest fort in the Koyna Wildlife Sanctuary
notes: A challenging jungle trek, different from the coastal Jaigad fort.

name: Kailasgad
key_events: A small fort overlooking the backwaters of Mulshi dam
notes: A short trek ideal for beginners.

name: Kakati Fort
key_events: A small village fortification or 'gadi'
notes: Very little remains of this small fort.

name: Kala Killa
key_events: Local name for the Dharavi or Riwa fort
notes: Note: This is an alternate name for Riwa Fort (ID 170).

name: Kaladgad
key_events: A small watchtower fort near Mangaon
notes: A simple trek with few remains of the fort.

name: Kalanidhigad
key_events: Guarded the Parpoli Ghat
notes: A scenic fort with lush green surroundings in the monsoon.

name: Kalavantin Durg
key_events: Watchtower for Prabalgad fort
notes: Famous for its breathtaking zigzag rock-cut steps and steep drop.

name: Kaldurg
key_events: Watchtower fort near Palghar
notes: Note: This is a duplicate entry for Kaldurg Fort (ID 080).

name: Kaldurg Fort
key_events: Watchtower fort near Palghar
notes: A rectangular-shaped fort with two distinct levels.

name: Kalyangad
key_events: One of the 11 forts built by King Bhoj II of Panhala
notes: Features a large cave with a temple of Lord Hanuman.

name: Kamalgad
key_events: Known for its unique natural rock structure with a hole
notes: A flat-topped fort, also called 'Navra-Navri' Dongar by locals.

name: Kamandurg
key_events: A difficult-to-access fort deep in the Tungareshwar Wildlife Sanctuary
notes: The trek is challenging due to dense forest and lack of a clear path.

name: Kanakdurg
key_events: Land-based fort connected to the sea fort Suvarnadurg
notes: Note: This is a duplicate entry for Goa Fort (Harnai) (ID 266).

name: Kanchangad
key_events: A small hill fort with a bastion and a few cisterns
notes: Offers good views of Vardhangad and surrounding areas.

name: Kandhar Fort
key_events: A large land fort with a moat filled with water
notes: Known for its massive gates and an imposing citadel.

name: Kanhergad
key_events: Watchtower fort in the Satmala range
notes: A lesser-known trek offering good views.

name: Kankrala Fort
key_events: Part of the Galna hill range
notes: A small fort with remnants of walls and cisterns.

name: Karha Fort
key_events: Small hill fort
notes: Mostly in ruins with a small temple at the top.

name: Karmala Fort
key_events: A land fort with a large well and a temple
notes: The fort is located inside Karmala town.

name: Karnala Fort
key_events: Known for its 125 ft high volcanic plug called Pandu's tower
notes: Located within the Karnala Bird Sanctuary.

name: Katora Fort
key_events: Small fort near Ambagad
notes: A minor fortification now mostly earthen mounds remain.

name: Katra Fort
key_events: A small fort near the confluence of Godavari and Indravati rivers
notes: Located in a remote area now mostly in ruins.

name: Kauthigad
key_events: Small fort near Sudhagad
notes: A small trek often visited along with Sudhagad fort.

name: Kavnai
key_events: Used as a prison by the Mughals
notes: Note: This is a duplicate entry for Kavnai Fort (ID 091).

name: Kelve Fort
key_events: A land-based fort near Kelve beach
notes: Not to be confused with the Kelve Pankot (sea fort).

name: Kelve Mahim
key_events: A coastal fort that was the seat of the local administration
notes: A large but completely ruined fort in the town of Mahim Palghar.

name: Kelve Pankot
key_events: A small sea fort to protect the Kelve creek
notes: Accessible by walking during low tide from Kelve beach.

name: Kenjalgad
key_events: Captured by Shivaji Maharaj; one of his last conquests
notes: A flat-topped fort that is easy to climb, with great views of the Krishna river valley.

name: Khairai
key_events: A small fort near Rohida
notes: Often visited by trekkers exploring the Bhor region.

name: Khanderi
key_events: Built to check the Siddis at Janjira; has a lighthouse
notes: Island fort accessible by boat; paired with the Underi fort.

name: Kharda Fort
key_events: Site of the Battle of Kharda, 1795, between Marathas and the Nizam
notes: A land fort known for its historical battle.

name: Kharepatan
key_events: Ancient port town fort on the banks of Vaghotan river
notes: Only remnants of the walls can be seen today.

name: Khubladha Fort
key_events: A small hillock with some fortifications near Manmad
notes: Lesser-known and with minimal remains.

name: Kohoj Fort
key_events: Known for its unique man-shaped pinnacle
notes: Offers a panoramic view of the Palghar region's lakes.

name: Kolaba Fort
key_events: Major naval station for the Maratha Navy under Sarkhel Kanhoji Angre
notes: Accessible by foot during low tide and by boat during high tide from Alibag beach.

name: Koldher Fort
key_events: Small watchtower fort
notes: A lesser-known fort in the Satmala range.

name: Koldurg
key_events: A small fort near Ghangad
notes: Often visited along with Ghangad fort.

name: Kolkewadi Fort
key_events: Fort overlooking the Kolkewadi Dam
notes: The fort area is mostly within the dam premises.

name: Kondhavi
key_events: A small fort on the banks of the Kundalika river
notes: Minimal ruins remain.

name: Korigad
key_events: Captured and incorporated into Swarajya; has two large ponds on top
notes: A popular trek near Lonavala and Aamby Valley; fort walls are completely intact.

name: Korlai Fort
key_events: Guarded the Revdanda creek; captured by Marathas
notes: A massive Portuguese fort with 11 gates and a lighthouse; known for its unique Creole language-speaking villagers.

name: Kotakmate Fort
key_events: Small coastal watchtower near Devgad
notes: Offers views of the Arabian sea and Devgad port.

name: Kulang Fort
key_events: Part of the intense Alang-Madan-Kulang trek
notes: The largest of the AMK trio; requires a long and strenuous trek.

name: Kunjargad
key_events: Watchtower fort in the Kalsubai range
notes: A small fort offering splendid views of Harishchandragad, Ratangad and Kalsubai.

name: Kurdugad
key_events: Used as a prison; renamed Vishramgad after the goddess Kurdai
notes: Features a large cave, granaries and a bastion in good condition.

name: Laling Fort
key_events: Controlled the strategic route from north India to Deccan
notes: The fort lies on the Mumbai-Agra highway and is easily accessible.

name: Lingana
key_events: Used as a penal colony by the Marathas
notes: A massive pinnacle near Raigad and Torna; requires technical rock climbing.

name: Lohagad
key_events: Used to store treasury from Surat loot by Shivaji Maharaj
notes: Known for its 'Vinchukata' (scorpion's tail) fortified spur and intact gates.

name: Machnur Fort
key_events: Small village fortification on the banks of the Bhima river
notes: A small gadi now mostly in ruins.

name: Madangad
key_events: Part of the intense Alang-Madan-Kulang trek
notes: The middle fort of the AMK trio; has a challenging rock patch for climbing.

name: Madh Fort
key_events: A watchtower fort guarding the Marve Creek
notes: Located on Madh Island, under the control of the Indian Air Force, access may be restricted.

name: Mahadevgad
key_events: A hillock near Mahuli with some signs of fortification
notes: Often considered a part of the greater Mahuli fort range.

name: Mahim Fort
key_events: Strategic fort in Mahim Bay; captured by Portuguese, then Marathas
notes: Heavily encroached upon; offers a view of the Bandra-Worli Sea Link.

name: Mahimangad
key_events: Guarded the eastern frontier of Swarajya
notes: A straightforward trek with a Hanuman temple at the top.

name: Mahimatgad
key_events: One of the largest forts in Ratnagiri; captured by Shivaji Maharaj in 1661
notes: Note: This is an alternate name for Mahipatgad (ID 109).

name: Mahipalgad
key_events: One of the largest forts in Ratnagiri; captured by Shivaji Maharaj in 1661
notes: Note: This is an alternate name for Mahipatgad (ID 109).

name: Mahipatgad
key_events: One of the largest forts in Ratnagiri; captured by Shivaji Maharaj in 1661
notes: A vast plateau fort with dense forest cover.

name: Mahuli Fort
key_events: Site of a fierce battle in 1670; has many pinnacles like Navra, Navri
notes: Highest point in Thane district; a popular trekking destination.

name: Makarandgad
key_events: Served as a watchtower for Pratapgad and Mahabaleshwar
notes: Also known as the Saddleback fort due to its shape.

name: Malanggad
key_events: Famous for the shrine (dargah) of Haji Abd-ul-Rahman
notes: A unique fort with three levels and a popular pilgrimage center.

name: Malegaon Fort
key_events: A large land fort on the banks of the Mausam river
notes: The fort walls now enclose several schools and government offices.

name: Malhargad
key_events: Last fort built by the Marathas; named after Lord Malhar
notes: A small fort with two temples in good condition.

name: Manaranjan Fort
key_events: Part of the Rajmachi twin-fort complex, faces west
notes: One of the two citadels of Rajmachi, simpler to climb than Shrivardhan.

name: Mandangad Fort
key_events: Has a large cannon named 'Top of the Mandan'
notes: Easily accessible from Mandangad town.

name: Mangad Fort
key_events: Guarded the route from Nizampur to Mahad
notes: Features a unique cave called 'Chor-darwaza' or secret door.

name: Mangalgad
key_events: Captured by Shivaji Maharaj in 1648
notes: A remote fort with a beautiful temple at the top.

name: Mangalvedha Fort
key_events: An ancient fort associated with Saint Damaji
notes: Only a bastion and a few walls remain of the original fort.

name: Mangi-Tungi
key_events: Major Jain pilgrimage center
notes: Known for its twin peaks and the world's tallest Jain statue of Lord Rishabhanatha.

name: Manikgad
key_events: Built to overlook the trade route through Bor Ghat
notes: A conical fort with a large depression at the center.

name: Manikgad
key_events: A large fort with extensive ramparts and gates
notes: Located in a dense forest.

name: Manikpunj
key_events: A small hillock fort
notes: Lesser known fort with minimal remains.

name: Manjarsumbha
key_events: A hill fort with a dargah at the top
notes: Offers a panoramic view of the Balaghat range.

name: Manohargad
key_events: Guarded the Ranganagad-Sawantwadi route
notes: A twin fort to Mansantoshgad.

name: Mansantoshgad
key_events: Twin fort to Manohargad
notes: Visited along with Manohargad fort.

name: Markandeya Fort
key_events: Known for the Markandeya Rishi temple, offers views of Saptashrungi
notes: A pilgrimage spot and a fort with a vast plateau.

name: Mazagon Fort
key_events: One of the forts protecting Mumbai harbour; blown up by Siddi
notes: No trace of the fort remains; the area is now Joseph Baptista Gardens.

name: Mirgad (Songir)
key_events: A very small fort near Songir
notes: This is a very minor fortification.

name: Mohandar Fort
key_events: Watchtower fort in the Dindori range
notes: A simple trek with good views of the surrounding area.

name: Mohangad
key_events: A subsidiary fort to Rohida
notes: A small fort with remnants of a gate and cisterns.

name: Mora Fort
key_events: A small hill fort in the Satmala range
notes: Lesser known fort often combined with a visit to Mulher.

name: Mordhan
key_events: A hill fort with a few cisterns and ruins
notes: Known for its scenic trek.

name: Morgiri Fort
key_events: A small watchtower fort near Lohagad
notes: A very small fort often visited by trekkers going to Lohagad.

name: Mrugagad
key_events: Known for its thrilling rock-cut steps and narrow climb
notes: A small, scenic fort ideal for a one-day trek.

name: Mudgad
key_events: Ancient Gond fort in a dense forest
notes: Located in a remote and densely forested area.

name: Mukutgad
key_events: Fortress on the Wainganga river
notes: Another ancient Gond fort now mostly in ruins.

name: Mulher Fort
key_events: Capital of the Bagul kingdom; site of a major Mughal-Maratha battle
notes: A massive fort complex along with Mora and Hatgad forts.

name: Murud-Janjira
key_events: Remained unconquered by Marathas; Portuguese; and British
notes: Accessible by sailboat from Rajpuri jetty; has 3 massive cannons.

name: Nagardhan
key_events: An ancient capital of the Vakataka dynasty
notes: A square-shaped land fort with bastions and a well-preserved wall.

name: Nagla Bunder Fort
key_events: A small watchtower on the Thane creek
notes: Located deep inside the mangrove forests of the Sanjay Gandhi National Park.

name: Naldurg Fort
key_events: Famous for its unique Pani Mahal (Water Palace) built across the Bori river
notes: An excellent example of Indo-Islamic architecture.

name: Nanded Fort
key_events: Located on the banks of Godavari river
notes: The fort area is now heavily encroached by the city.

name: Naneghat
key_events: Ancient trade route pass with caves and inscriptions
notes: Famous for its inscriptions and the reverse waterfall during monsoon.

name: Narayangad
key_events: Strengthened during the Peshwa period
notes: A small fort known for its temple of Hastabai.

name: Narayangad (Amboli)
key_events: A small fort near Amboli Ghat
notes: A view point in Amboli, with very few remains of the fort.

name: Narnala Fort
key_events: Part of Melghat Tiger Reserve; consists of three forts: Zafarabad, Narnala, and Teliagarh
notes: A vast hill fort with impressive gates and a beautiful mosque.

name: Narsinhagad
key_events: Small fort dedicated to Lord Narasimha
notes: A pilgrimage spot with ruins of fortifications.

name: Nhavigad
key_events: Watchtower in the Satmala range
notes: Provides good views of the surrounding forts like Patta.

name: Nimgiri Fort
key_events: Twin fort to Hanumantgad; has several rock-cut cisterns
notes: Known for its step-well and rock-cut architecture.

name: Nivati Fort
key_events: Coastal watchtower fort overlooking Nivati beach and Bhogwe beach
notes: Offers stunning views of the Karli river estuary.

name: Pabargad
key_events: A small fort near the Kalsubai range
notes: A challenging trek with a rock patch.

name: Padargad
key_events: Watchtower for Bhimashankar; extremely difficult climb
notes: Features a natural chimney climb and high exposure.

name: Padmadurg
key_events: Built to counter Janjira fort; shaped like a lotus
notes: A sea fort near Murud-Janjira, accessible by boat but requires permission.

name: Padmagad
key_events: A sea fort built to protect Devgad fort
notes: Not to be confused with Padmadurg near Murud. Most of it is submerged.

name: Padmagad (Malwan)
key_events: A coastal watchtower fort
notes: Note: This likely refers to Sarjekot (ID 178) or another minor fortification near Malvan, not to be confused with Padmadurg (ID 144).

name: Pal Fort
key_events: A fort in the Koyna region associated with Saint Ramdas
notes: A small fort with a Maruti temple.

name: Palgad
key_events: Birthplace of the social reformer Sane Guruji is at the base
notes: A small fort with historical connections to the Konkan region.

name: Palshi Fort
key_events: A small fortified mansion or 'gadi'
notes: Located within Palshi village; very little remains.

name: Pandavgad
key_events: Believed to be a place of stay for the Pandavas
notes: The fort has a large plateau and several rock-cut water cisterns.

name: Panhala Fort
key_events: Famous for Shivaji's escape to Vishalgad; has extensive fortifications
notes: A major hill station with a fort that housed Shivaji Maharaj for over 500 days.

name: Panhale Durg
key_events: A group of rock-cut caves with some fortifications
notes: More known as a complex of Buddhist and Hindu caves than a fort.

name: Paranda Fort
key_events: A fine example of military architecture; has a large number of cannons
notes: Known for its well-preserved bastions, moat, and the 'Mulik-e-Maidan' cannon.

name: Pargad
key_events: Built to defend the southern border of Swarajya
notes: The fort is still inhabited by descendants of its original defenders.

name: Parola Fort
key_events: A large land fort built by the Newalkar family
notes: A significant landmark in Parola town, though largely in ruins.

name: Parvatgad (Nashik)
key_events: A small fort used as a watchtower
asi_protected: Lesser-known fort in the Dindori range.

name: Pateshwar
key_events: A religious place with 8 ancient cave temples of Lord Shiva
notes: More of a pilgrimage site with caves than a fort.

name: Patta Fort
key_events: Shivaji Maharaj rested here during his retreat from Surat; hence named Vishramgad
notes: Has a large cave and is accessible via a well-defined path.

name: Pavangad
key_events: A sister fort to Panhala; captured by the British in 1844
notes: Located very close to Panhala fort.

name: Peb Fort
key_events: Named after goddess Pebi; offers views of Matheran toy train
notes: A popular trek near Matheran; can be reached via the Matheran railway line.

name: Pemgiri Fort
key_events: Used as a state prison by the Nizam Shahi dynasty
notes: Also known as Shahagad; features large caves.

name: Piliv Fort
key_events: A land fort or 'gadi' in the village
notes: A few walls and a bastion are all that remain.

name: Pimpla Fort
key_events: A small fort in the Satmala range
notes: A remote fort with very few trekkers.

name: Pimplaskot
key_events: A small hill fort with minimal remains
notes: A very obscure fort.

name: Pisol Fort
key_events: A very small watchtower
notes: Only a small plinth and a water cistern remain.

name: Prabalgad
key_events: Captured by Shivaji Maharaj; Umaji Naik fought against the British from here
notes: A large plateau fort next to the famous Kalavantin Durg pinnacle.

name: Prachitgad
key_events: A remote fort in the Sahyadris with dense forest cover
notes: One of the toughest treks in the Konkan region.

name: Pratapgad
key_events: Meeting and slaying of Afzal Khan, 1659
notes: Features a temple to Goddess Bhavani and a statue of Shivaji Maharaj.

name: Purandar Fort
key_events: Birthplace of Sambhaji Maharaj; site of the Treaty of Purandar, 1665
notes: Consists of two forts: Purandar and Vajragad; partly controlled by the Indian Army.

name: Purnagad
key_events: Guarded the mouth of the Muchkundi River
notes: A small but well-preserved fort with a Hanuman temple at the entrance.

name: Raigad Fort
key_events: Capital of Maratha Empire; Coronation of Shivaji Maharaj, 1674
accommodation: MTDC Resort at base; Dharmashala on top
notes: Has a ropeway for easy access; Holds the samadhi of Shivaji Maharaj.

name: Raikot
key_events: A small village 'gadi'
notes: Hardly any remains of the fortification exist.

name: Raireshwar
key_events: Site where Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj took the oath of Hindavi Swarajya
notes: A large plateau with a temple more of a historical site than a fort.

name: Rajapur Fort
key_events: A land fort to protect the port town of Rajapur
notes: The fort is now completely integrated into the town.

name: Rajdher Fort
key_events: A hill fort near Chandwad
notes: Known for its rock-cut steps and a large cave.

name: Rajgad Fort
key_events: Served as Maratha capital for over 25 years before Raigad
notes: Known for its three machis (plateaus): Padmavati, Suvela, and Sanjeevani.

name: Rajkot
key_events: A small fortified 'gadi'
notes: Located inside the town now in complete ruins.

name: Rajmachi
key_events: Comprises two forts: Shrivardhan and Manaranjan; overlooks Bor Ghat
notes: A popular long trek, also accessible by a rough road from Lonavala.

name: Ramdurg
key_events: A small hillock with a temple and minimal fortifications
notes: A local religious spot.

name: Ramgad
key_events: A small fort near Pen
notes: Very little remains of this fort.

name: Ramsej Fort
key_events: Famously withstood a Mughal siege for over 6 years
notes: A fort of great historical importance for Maratha resilience.

name: Ramtek Fort
key_events: A major pilgrimage site associated with Lord Rama and Kalidasa
notes: A religious site with strong fortifications on a hill.

name: Rangna Fort
key_events: A large and remote forest fort
notes: Known for its natural beauty and robust fortifications.

name: Ranjangiri
key_events: A small hill fort with a few remains
notes: Not to be confused with Ranjangaon Mahaganapati Temple.

name: Rasalgad
key_events: Paired with Sumargad and Mahipatgad to defend the region
notes: A small and well-maintained fort.

name: Rasalpur Sarai
key_events: A fortified inn on the historical trade route
notes: Note: This is a fortified inn (Sarai), not a fort, located in Madhya Pradesh near the Maharashtra border.

name: Ratangad
key_events: The 'Jewel' fort; famous for its 'Nedhe' or Needle Hole
notes: Offers spectacular views of the Bhandardara dam and surrounding peaks.

name: Ratangad (Raigad district)
key_events: A very obscure fort
notes: Note: An extremely obscure fort, not to be confused with the famous Ratangad in Ahmednagar (ID 167).

name: Ratnadurg
key_events: Main fort guarding Ratnagiri; has a famous Bhagwati temple
notes: A horseshoe-shaped fort covering a large area, with a lighthouse.

name: Rawlya Fort
key_events: Twin fort to Jawlya
notes: Offers great views of the surrounding Satmala range.

name: Revdanda Fort
key_events: A large coastal fort enclosing the village of Revdanda
notes: The fort walls are now covered with palm trees and houses.

name: Riwa Fort
key_events: Built to mark the northern boundary of British-held Bombay
notes: Now houses the Bombay Presidency Radio Club; overlooks the Mithi River.

name: Rohida Fort
key_events: One of the first forts captured by Shivaji Maharaj
notes: Known for its well-maintained bastions and gates (darwajas).

name: Rohilgad
key_events: A small fort with a few structures and a dargah
notes: A lesser-known fort in the Jalna district.

name: Sadashivgad
key_events: A hill fort with a famous Shiva temple
notes: A popular pilgrimage site accessible by road.

name: Sagargad
key_events: A coastal fort known for its waterfall during monsoon
notes: The trek to the fort passes the famous Dodhane waterfall.

name: Sajjangad
key_events: Final resting place (Samadhi) of Samarth Ramdas Swami
notes: A major pilgrimage center for the Ramdasi sect accessible by road.

name: Salher Fort
key_events: Highest fort in Maharashtra; site of the pivotal Battle of Salher (1672)
notes: Offers panoramic views and has a Parshuram temple.

name: Salota Fort
key_events: A twin fort to Salher
notes: Usually trekked along with Salher fort.

name: Samangad
key_events: A small fort with a large plateau
notes: Known for its Bhimsen temple and beautiful surroundings.

name: Samrajgad
key_events: A small sea fort near Murud-Janjira
notes: Built to support Padmadurg against the Siddis.

name: Sangram Durg
key_events: Famous for the valiant defence by Firangoji Narsala against Shaista Khan
notes: A land fort in the middle of Chakan town; has a moat and strong walls.

name: Santoshgad
key_events: A hill fort near Phaltan
notes: Also known as 'Fort of the Pandavas' by locals.

name: Saptashrungi
key_events: A major Hindu pilgrimage site with fortifications on the hill
notes: The hill has one of the 51 Shakti Peethas; accessible by road and funicular ropeway.

name: Sarasgad
key_events: Overlooks the famous Ballaleshwar temple of Pali (Ashtavinayak)
notes: A twin fort to Sudhagad.

name: Sarjekot (Alibaug)
key_events: A small coastal fortification near Alibag
notes: A minor naval outpost, different from Sarjekot near Malvan.

name: Sarjekot Fort
key_events: Built as a naval outpost and dockyard for Sindhudurg
notes: A small coastal fort at the mouth of the Kalavali creek.

name: Satavali
key_events: A small coastal watchtower
notes: Hardly any remains of the fort are visible.

name: Sewri Fort
key_events: Built to defend Mumbai harbour from the Siddis
notes: Offers excellent views of flamingoes at the Sewri mudflats during winter.

name: Shahagad
key_events: Another name for Pemgiri Fort
notes: Features large caves and was used as a prison.

name: Shirgaon Fort
key_events: Coastal fort to keep watch on Portuguese activities
notes: Located on Shirgaon beach; has a famous dargah inside.

name: Shivgad
key_events: Small watchtower fort near Raigad
notes: A remote fort with limited remains.

name: Shivneri
key_events: Birthplace of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, 1630
notes: Features a temple of goddess Shivai and statues of Jijabai and a young Shivaji.

name: Shrivardhan Fort
key_events: Eastern citadel of the Rajmachi twin-fort complex
notes: The more complex of the two Rajmachi citadels to climb.

name: Siddhagad
key_events: Site of a fierce battle during the 1857 uprising
notes: A large plateau fort with dense vegetation and a memorial.

name: Siddhagad (Malwan)
key_events: A small coastal fort
notes: A local fort, not to be confused with Siddhagad near Murbad.

name: Sindhudurg
key_events: Main naval base for the Maratha Navy
notes: Spread over 48 acres, its walls were designed to be invisible from the sea.

name: Sinhagad
key_events: Battle of Sinhagad, 1670, led by Tanaji Malusare
notes: Famous for pithla-bhakri stalls; Accessible by road to the top.

name: Sion Hillock Fort
key_events: Built to mark the boundary between British-held Bombay and Portuguese-held Salsette Island
notes: Located at the top of a hillock, now a garden.

name: Sondai Fort
key_events: A small watchtower fort
notes: A short and scenic trek; features two water cisterns and a small idol of Sondai devi.

name: Songad
key_events: A watchtower fort near Mahad
notes: Note: This is a duplicate entry for Songad Fort (ID 190).

name: Songad (Nashik)
key_events: A small hillock fort
notes: A very obscure fort with minimal ruins.

name: Songad Fort
key_events: A watchtower fort near Mahad
notes: A small fort with minimal remains.

name: Songir (Dhule)
key_events: A prominent fort on the Mumbai-Agra highway
notes: Features a deep well and ruins of several structures.

name: Songir (Karjat)
key_events: A small fort near the base of Rajmachi
notes: A very small fortification often overlooked by trekkers.

name: Subhan Mangal
key_events: A small fortification inside the main Solapur Fort (Bhuikot)
notes: Likely refers to a bastion or inner citadel of the Solapur Fort.

name: Sudhagad
key_events: Was considered by Shivaji Maharaj for the capital before Raigad
notes: A large plateau fort with lakes and a temple.

name: Sumargad
key_events: Part of a trio of forts with Rasalgad and Mahipatgad
notes: A very remote and difficult fort to access.

name: Surgad
key_events: Watchtower fort near the Kundalika river
notes: Known for its rock-cut steps and small caves called 'man-made pindas'.

name: Suvarnadurg
key_events: A major naval base of the Marathas, connected to the land by Kanakdurg
notes: The 'Golden Fort' is a sea fort near Harnai port, accessible by boat.

name: Tahuli Fort
key_events: A pinnacle fort with three pinnacles
notes: Known for its scenic and challenging trail.

name: Talagad
key_events: Twin fort to Ghosalgad
notes: Features a large plateau and several water cisterns.

name: Tandulwadi
key_events: A large plateau fort near Saphale
notes: Offers panoramic views of the surrounding coastal area.

name: Tankai Fort
key_events: Twin fort to Ankai
notes: Visited along with Ankai fort.

name: Tarapur Fort
key_events: Captured by the Marathas under Chimaji Appa
notes: Located near the Tarapur Atomic Power Station, now largely in ruins.

name: Terekhol Fort
key_events: Captured by Portuguese in 1746; used by freedom fighters in 1954
notes: Located at the mouth of the Terekhol River, now a heritage hotel.

name: Thalner Fort
key_events: First capital of the Khandesh Sultanate
notes: Located on the banks of the Tapi river.

name: Tikona
key_events: Known for its triangular shape and a large cave
notes: A popular and easy trek near Pawna Lake.

name: Torna Fort
key_events: First fort captured by Shivaji Maharaj at age 16; renamed Prachandagad (Massive Fort)
notes: Its large size and historical importance make it a key fort in Maratha history.

name: Tringalwadi Fort
key_events: Overlooks the Thal Ghat trade route; has Jain caves at its base
notes: The top of the fort is shaped like a turban, offering great views of the Kalsubai range.

name: Tung Fort
key_events: Served as a watchtower for the Bhor ghat and Pawna Maval region
notes: A sharp, conical fort offering stunning panoramic views of the Pawna Lake.

name: Udgir Fort
key_events: Site of the Battle of Udgir (1760) where Marathas defeated the Nizam
notes: A land fort with a 40-foot deep moat, known for its underground rooms and a Samadhi of Udaygir Maharaj.

name: Underi Fort
key_events: Built by the Siddis to challenge the Marathas at Khanderi
notes: A fortified island, smaller than its counterpart Khanderi; requires a boat and permission to visit.

name: Vairatgad
key_events: Guarded the route between Wai and the coastal regions
notes: A small fort with remnants of bastions and a Hanuman temple.

name: Vajragad
key_events: Twin fort of Purandar; captured by Shivaji's forces in 1665 by Dilerkhan
notes: Often visited along with Purandar fort, features a temple of Lord Rudreshwar.

name: Vajragad (Vasai)
key_events: A specific bastion or section of the main Vasai fort
notes: Note: This is not a separate fort but likely refers to a bastion within the vast Vasai Fort (ID 211).

name: Vandan Fort
key_events: Twin fort to Chandan; captured by Shivaji Maharaj
notes: Usually trekked along with Chandan fort from the base village.

name: Vardhangad
key_events: Built to secure the eastern frontier of the Maratha kingdom
notes: Easily accessible by road; the fort has a temple of the goddess Vardhini.

name: Varugad
key_events: A double-layered fort built to provide defense to the region
notes: Has two sections (machis) at different levels, connected by a strong fortification.

name: Vasai Fort
era: Sultanate of Gujarat; Portuguese; Maratha Empire
key_events: Capital of the Portuguese province of the North; captured by Chimaji Appa in 1739
notes: A vast fort complex with remnants of churches, administrative buildings, and bastions.

name: Vasantgad
key_events: Guarded the Karad region; has a well-preserved Chandrasen Maharaj temple
notes: Known for its robust fortifications and a historical well called 'Goleshwarachi Vihir'.

name: Vasota Fort
key_events: The 'Jungle Fort' located deep within the Koyna Wildlife Sanctuary
notes: Accessible by a boat ride from Bamnoli across the Shivsagar lake; requires forest dept. Permission.

name: Vengurla Fort
key_events: A fortified Dutch factory
notes: Also known as the 'Burnt Islands'; accessible by boat.

name: Vetalgad
key_events: A small fort in the Kalwan range
notes: Minimal ruins remain.

name: Vetalwadi Fort
key_events: A fort guarding the Vetalwadi ghats
notes: Known for its two-storey palace-like structure.

name: Vijaydurg
key_events: One of the strongest Maratha naval bases under Kanhoji Angre; has an underwater wall
notes: The 'Victory Fort' is one of the best-preserved sea forts; has a triple line of fortifications.

name: Vilasgad (Mallikarjun)
key_events: A small hill with a Mallikarjun temple and some fortifications
notes: A local pilgrimage spot.

name: Visapur Fort
key_events: Twin fort to Lohagad; built to guard it
notes: Known for its huge plateau, numerous water cisterns, and a scenic waterfall trail in monsoon.

name: Vishalgad
key_events: Where Shivaji Maharaj escaped to after fleeing Panhala; has the samadhi of Baji Prabhu Deshpande nearby
notes: A large fort with significant historical monuments, including a dargah and temples.

name: Worli Fort
key_events: A small watchtower built to keep an eye on enemy ships
notes: Located at the tip of Worli village, offering views of the Bandra-Worli Sea Link.

name: Yashawantgad (Nate)
key_events: A coastal fort guarding the Nate creek
notes: A different fort from Yashwantgad/Redi Fort in Sindhudurg district.

name: Yashwantgad
key_events: A coastal fort guarding the Terekhol creek
notes: Overlooks the beautiful Redi beach and is covered in dense vegetation.
